As then, no winde at all there blew,</br>No swelling cloude accloid the aire,</br>The skie, like grasse of watchet hew,</br>Reflected Phoebus golden haire,</br>The garnisht tree, no pendant stird;</br>No voice was heard of anie Bird.

There might you see the burly Beare,</br>The Lion king, the Elephant,</br>The maiden Unicorne was there;</br>So was Acteons horned plant,</br>And what of wilde or tame are found,</br>Were coucht in order on the ground.

Alcides speckled poplar tree,</br>The palme that Monarchs do obtaine,</br>With love juice staind the mulberie,</br>The fruit that dewes the Poets brain,</br>And Phillis philbert there away,</br>Comparde with mirtle and the bay.

The tree that coffins doth adorne,</br>With stately height threatning the skie,</br>And for the bed of Love forlorne,</br>The blacke and dolefull Ebonie;</br>All in a circle compast were,</br>Like to an Ampitheater.

Upon the branches of those trees,</br>The airie winged people sat,</br>Distinguished in od degrees,</br>One sort is this, another that,</br>Here Philomell, that knowes full well,</br>What force and wit in love doth dwell.

The skiebred Egle roiall bird,</br>Percht there upon an oke above,</br>The Turtle by him never stird,</br>Example of immortall love.</br>The Swan that sings about to dy,</br>Leaving Meander stood thereby.

And that which was of woonder most,</br>The Phoenix left sweet Arabie:</br>And on a Cedar in this coast,</br>Built up her tombe of spicerie,</br>As I conjecture by the same,</br>Preparde to take her dying flame.

In midst and center of this plot,</br>I saw one groveling on the grasse:</br>A man or stone, I knew not that,</br>No stone, of man the figure was,</br>And yet I could not count him one,</br>More than the image made of stone.

At length I might perceive him reare</br>His bodie on his elbow end:</br>Earthly and pale with gastly cheare,</br>Upon his knees he upward tend,</br>Seeming like one in uncouth stound,</br>To be ascending out the ground.

A grievous sigh forthwith he throwes,</br>As might have torne the vitall strings,</br>Then down his cheeks the teares so flows,</br>As doth the streame of many springs.</br>So thunder rends the cloud in twaine,</br>And makes a passage for the raine.

Incontinent with trembling sound,</br>He wofully gan to complaine,</br>Such were the accents as might wound,</br>And teare a diamond rocke in twaine,</br>After his throbs did somewhat stay,</br>Thus heavily he gan to say.

O sunne (said he) seeing the sunne,</br>On wretched me why dost thou shine,</br>My star is falne, my comfort done,</br>Out is the apple of mine eine,</br>Shine upon those possesse delight,</br>And let me live in endlesse night.

O griefe that liest upon my soule,</br>As heavie as a mount of lead,</br>The temnant of my life controll,</br>Consort me quickly with the dead,</br>Halfe of this hart, this sprite and will,</br>Di'de in the brest of Astrophill.

And you compassionate of my wo,</br>Gentle birds, beasts, and shadie trees,</br>I am assurde ye long to kno,</br>What be the sorrowes me aggriev's,</br>Listen ye then to that insu'th,</br>And hear a tale of teares and ruthe.

You knew, who knew not Astrophill,</br>(That I should live to say I knew,</br>And have not in possession still)</br>Things knowne permit me to renew</br>Of him you know his merit such,</br>I cannot say, you heare too much.

Within these woods of Arcadie</br>He chief delight and pleasure tooke,</br>And on the mountaine Parthenie,</br>Upon the chrystall liquid brooke,</br>The Muses met him ev'ry day,</br>That taught him sing, to write, and say,

When he descended down the mount,</br>His personage seemed more divine,</br>A thousand graces one might count,</br>Upon his lovely cheerfull eine,</br>To hear him speake and sweetly smile,</br>You were in Paradise the while.

A sweet attractive kinde of grace,</br>A full assurance given by lookes,</br>Continuall comfort in a face,</br>The lineaments of Gospell bookes,</br>I trowe that countenance cannot lie,</br>Whose thoughts are legible in the eie.

Was never eie, did see that face,</br>Was never eare, did heare that tong,</br>Was never minde, did minde his grace,</br>That ever thought the travell long,</br>But eies, and eares, and every thought,</br>Were with his sweete perfections caught.

O God, that such a worthy man,</br>In whom so rare desarts did raigne,</br>Desired thus, must leave us than,</br>And we to wish for him in vaine,</br>O could the stars that bred that wit,</br>In force no longer fixed sit.

Then being fild with learned dew,</br>The Muses willed him to love,</br>That instrument can aptly shew,</br>How finely our conceits will move,</br>As Bacchus opes dissembled harts,</br>So love sets out our better parts.

Stella, a Nymph within this wood,</br>Most rare and rich of heav'nly blis,</br>The highest in his fancie stood,</br>And she could well demerite this:</br>'Tis likely they acquainted soone,</br>He was a Sun, and she a Moone.

Our Astrophill did Stella love,</br>O Stella vaunt of Astrophill,</br>Albeit thy graces gods may move,</br>Where wilt thou find an Astrophill,</br>The rose and lillie have their prime,</br>And so hath beautie but a time.

Although thy beautie do exceed,</br>In common sight of ev'ry eie,</br>Yet in his Poesies when we reede,</br>It is apparent more thereby,</br>He thee hath love and judgment too,</br>Sees more than any other doo.

Then Astrophill hath honord thee,</br>For when thy bodie is extinct,</br>Thy graces shall eternall be,</br>And live by vertue of his inke,</br>For by his verses he doth give,</br>To short livde beautie aye to live.

Above all others, this is hee,</br>Which erst approved in his song,</br>That love and honor might agree,</br>And that pure love will do no wrong.</br>Sweet saints, it is no sinne nor Blame</br>To love a man of vertuous name.

Did never love so sweetly breath</br>In any mortall brest before,</br>Did never Muse inspire beneath,</br>A Poets braine with finer store:</br>He wrote of love with high conceit,</br>And beautie reard above her height.

Then Pallas afterward attyrde,</br>Our Astrophill with her device,</br>Whom in his armor heaven admyrde,</br>As of the nation of the skies,</br>He sparkled in his armes afarrs,</br>As he were dight with fiery starrs.

The blaze whereof when Mars beheld,</br>(An envious eie doth see afar)</br>Such majesie (quoth he) is seeld,</br>Such majestie my mart may mar,</br>Perhaps this may a suter be,</br>To set Mars by his deitie.

In this surmize he made with speede,</br>An iron cane wherein he put,</br>The thunder that in cloudes doth breede,</br>The flame and bolt togither shut,</br>With privie force burst out againe,</br>And so our Astrophill was slaine.

This word (was slaine) straightway did move,</br>And nature's inward life strings twitch;</br>The skie immediately above,</br>Was dimd with hideous clouds of pitch,</br>The wrastling winds from out the ground,</br>Fild all the aire with ratling sound.

The bending trees exprest a grone,</br>And sighd the sorrow of his fall;</br>The forrest beasts made ruthfull mone,</br>The birds did tune their mourning call,</br>And Philomell for Astrophill,</br>Unto her notes annext a phill.

The Turtle dove, with Tunes of ruthe,</br>Shewd feeling passion of his death,</br>Me thought she said I tell the truthe,</br>Was never he that drew in breath,</br>Unto his love more trustie found,</br>Than he for whom our griefs abound.

The swan that was in presence heere,</br>Began his funerall dirge to sing,</br>Good things (quoth he) may scarce appeere,</br>But passe away with speedie wing.</br>This mortall life, as death is tride,</br>And death gives life, and so he di'de.

The general sorrow that was made,</br>Among the creatures of kinde,</br>Fired the Phoenix where she laide,</br>Her ashes flying with the winde,</br>So as I might with reason see,</br>That such a Phoenix nere should bee.

Haply the cinders driven about,</br>May breede an offspring neere that kinde,</br>But hardly a peere to that I doubt.</br>It cannot sinke into my minde,</br>That under branches ere can bee</br>Of worth and value as the tree.

The Egle markt with pearcing sight,</br>The mournfull habit of the place,</br>And parted thence with mounting flight,</br>To signifie to Jove the case,</br>What sorrow nature doth sustaine,</br>For Astrophill by envie slaine.

And while I followed with mine eie,</br>The flight the Egle upward tooke,</br>All things did vanish by and by,</br>And disappeared from my looke,</br>The trees, beasts, birds, and grove was gone,</br>So was the friend that made this mone.

This spectacle had firmly wrought,</br>A deep compassion in my spright,</br>My molting hart issude me thought,</br>In streames forth at mine eies aright,</br>And here my pen is forst to shrinke,</br>My teares discollors so mine inke.</br>
